name: Delta Dash Version 3.1 Beta
brief: The first BETA test stage, involving refined UI and game structure.
description:
Version 3.1 Beta introduces a polished user interface and multiple refinements to the gameplay loop. It is the first ever Beta version, a milestone on the course of game development and marketing. It will be the first time our customers see our product. 

 However, due to lack of funds, this version will only be released at small scale among our fans, and each user must produce the game itself from digital version in order to reduce an ~$2000 printing and transportation cost.

name: Delta Dash Version 3.0 Alpha
brief: Base version for Delta Dash 3.0 structure, with updates on track and UI.
description:
Version 3.0 Alpha is the foundational release for the 3.x series.

Highlights: core rule refactor, race track re-design, improved component layout and a base implementation for online matchmaking. This alpha focuses on establishing stable game rules and internal data models.

Notes for playtesters: expect rough edges in the user interface. The Alpha stage is primarily for testing core balance and identifying critical bugs before wider beta testing. 

 Though developed earlier than Beta 3.1, this version will be tested simultaneously with Beta 3.1 version.

name: Formula Champion 2.1 Alpha
brief: Last version of Formula Champion before rebranding to Delta Dash; includes bug fixes and minor improvements.
description: Version 2.1 Alpha focuses on bug fixes and minor improvements based on previous Alpha version tests, with the largest testing team ever occurred in the history of Geeks Production Studio.

name: Formula Champion 2.0 Alpha
brief: Major overhaul introducing new mechanics based on fans' interests.
description: Version 2.0 Alpha introduces significant changes to the core mechanics of Formula Champion, including a completely new gameplay mechanism, entirely refactored rule description and UI, introducing the 'delta' mechanism which turned the players' focus from pure racing to strategic resource management, also contributing to today's brand 'Delta Dash'.

name: Formula Champion 1.3 Alpha
brief: Last version of Formula Champion before the 'delta' mechanism introduction, a final judgement of the original mechanism.
description: Version 1.3 Alpha was said to be the final version of Formula Champion before release, involving a complete bug fix, but due to the negative feedbacks regarding the original mechanics, the development team decided to rework the entire game mechanics, leading to the birth of 2.0 and later versions and the awful reputation of the studio due to 'lack of progress management'.

name: Formula Champion 1.2 InDev
brief: An attempt to simplify previous generations but stopped due to personal issues.
description: Version 1.2 InDev, rebranded as 'Formula Champion', was an attempt to simplify the previous generations to make the game more playable, but due to personal issues, the development stopped before testing, leaving a flawed and 'bugful' in-dev version.

name: War of Formula Racing 1.1 Alpha
brief: A massive advancement including realistic enhance, but its complexity made it an awful product also.
description: Version 1.1 Alpha was an ultra-realistic version of 1.0 including realistic gear-shift data sheet, re-designed track for better data resolution, and refined UI using F1 font. However, its complexity made it almost unplayable without the developer as host and easy to crash, this version, though said 'better than 1.0', was still horrible as a product and not ready for publish.

name: War of Formula Racing 1.0 Alpha
brief: The first ever version, inspired by ChatGPT. It is simple but no fun at all.
description: Version 1.0 Alpha was the first ever version of this series, with a very coarse track and control system inspired by ChatGPT. It featured the most basic racing mechanism: control car speed, take steps on track forward, and not running too fast in the corners. The UI was also very coarse, as there was no driver panel and all control were memorized by the players and resources were represented by solid cards. However, its multi-lap strategy system and ineffective UI made the game extremely slow, and thus a failed project with no likes at all.
